107415624 How about you stop being an asshat and suggest a solution There's a couple of reasons why you have shit speakers and can hear a hissing sound 1 Shit speakers It's old like you said so it might have developed the hiss over time This always happens when using an active speaker Since you are using a 3 5mm jack I'm assuming you are using an active speaker and not a passive one 2 Your motherboard audio chip sucks This isn't new all motherboard chips sucks but they did get better over the years The downside to this is that it can amplifying the hissing sound of your speakers 3 Using an audio jack is the worst way to plug speakers in because it sends an analog signal to your speakers which is easier for interference to distort the sound So a couple of ways to fix this Get better speakers This is the expensive method All active speakers will eventually hiss But getting passive speakers can get expensive So your best option is to get speakers and replace them every 15 20 years Another way to combat this is to send a digital signal instead Drop the 3 5mm jack and use either optical or USB cables All modern active speakers should have a USB or optical input If you are dead set on using an analog signal then RCA audio jack Now if you bought an expensive passive speaker that only takes RCA input then you're going to need a DAC to take the digital signal to from your PC convert it to analog then and send it to an amplifier to power your passive speakers This is why passive speakers get expensive So may advice get better speakers that has optical or USB input

107418986 If the port is properly designed for it there's nothing inherently wrong with using USB C for charging The standard supports up to 240W power delivery at the high end which is usually enough even for laptops with discrete GPUs The main issue plaguing USB C everywhere is that 90 of the standard is optional So for example I can imagine a gaming laptop that has a high wattage proprietary charging port and a cheap anemic USB C charging port that accepts up to 45W just to be able to advertise USC C charging but you can only use it to trickle charge while not using your GPU as the other anon said Or it could be an afterthought and the charging circuit could be fucking garbage chinkshit quality But then the main charging circuit could be garbage quality too But assuming your laptop has proper USB C charging then yes you can use it And if it's not a gaming laptop and doesn't require tons of power then it's extremely unlikely you will have any issues IMO If it is a gaming laptop then hopefully they didn't cheap out on it

A review of Tails Protecting privacy with Tails Tails is an unusual Linux distribution developed by the Tor Project it is designed to help users work around internet censorship and avoid surveillance It is a portable operating system that is meant to be run from a USB stick or ISO image and to leave no trace on the computer it was run on Tails routes connections to the internet over the Tor network and includes a selection of applications and tools suited to working with sensitive documents communicating securely and preserving users' anonymity The tradeoff of course is that Tails is less convenient and requires users to learn a new set of tools to avoid compromising their own security and anonymity Tails 7 1 was released in October and it seemed like as good a time as any to take it for a spin

107419569 This filtered you because you're not good at designing algorithms in your head It's not that hard but there is some challenge in making your solution optimal There's two criteria in these sorts of tests Find out if you can do it at all Find out how well you can do it Off the top of my head I'd use the array as a row cursor into the virtual grid by decrementing all elements and comparing them to zero If they're greater than zero then they represent walls on the current run A second array stores cells that hold water and is incremented if the row cursor finds it's a valid water cell By parsing the array from zero to n one can hold a list of cells that are currently valid for water This is always false for the first cell in the zero column but once you hit a solid block you set a flag to say that there's a wall to your left and keep traversing the array When you hit an empty cell unset the wall flag and set the water flag and start adding cells to your valid water cells list When you hist another solid cell unset your water flag set your wall flag and add your valid water cells to the second array of water cells by incrementing those elements Clear your temporary water cells list and continue traversing the row At the end of the row you'll always fail the water test and clear the right most water cells because they leak out the edge of the grid Then you repeat the process by decrementing the array and starting again from zero When there are no non zero cells in the list stop processing The challenge isn't in doing this it's in optimising it and doing it efficiently They'll look for novel but elegant solutions they'll have a list of acceptable solutions and probably a list of naive solutions they reject out of hand

FFUCKK finally this is working I hate org indent mode so much I had a fix for preserving indentation in org transclusion like 2 months ago But the problem was that the fringes that are created to signal something was transcluded would be erased when the buffer refreshed This was due to how I changed fringes the chars in the left border from an overlay to simple text properties Well turns out that when a buffer refreshes org indent does a ton of shit to reapply indentation by going over the whole buffer applying line and wrap prefix to each line Since the fringe text property was also there they get replaced The only solution I found for this refresh issue was copying ern indent and bruteforce my way into org indent hooks and timers and redraw fringes after indent mode updates the text properties Haven't pushed this into the PR branch yet Makes sense why some packages don't even try to take org indent mode into account like org modern

107407335 I don't know what expressible is supposed to mean here Let's define it as a range of programs and algorithms it can correctly validate Writing C and then using external tools allows you to express your programs and their invariants much better than Rust That's wrong Rust has been designed with such static analysis in mind C static analyzers that eg attempt to track lifetimes generally do not allow you to express more complex lifetime bounds like Rust can It all also fails short when you call external code In general it's not as simple as writing C code and then running it through static analyzer You often need to provide it with extra information via comments and such to allow it to prove correctness And this is generally much more limiting in terms of what can be expressed in it than Rust syntax

After about eighteen months I started logging contacts that didn't fit known profiles First one was during a mid watch Range quiet no exercises scheduled Around 0340 I picked up broadband signal six nautical miles northeast of Site 1 Definitely not mechanical No shaft rate no blade count no machinery tonals Not biological either The frequency spread didn't match any cetacean in our database Contact traveled 28 nautical miles in twelve minutes Depth between 2 000 and 4 000 feet That's approximately 140 knots Mk 48 ADCAP maxes at 55 This was doing three times that with no cavitation Watch supervisor looked at it and told me log it as possible system artifact I asked about flagging for review He said no Over the next five years I logged fourteen similar contacts Broadband signature no mechanical source Speed typically 80 to 200 knots Variable depth sometimes rising from below 4 000 feet to 500 feet in seconds No cavitation no wake The problem was the BQQ 10 system logic It filters out non threats automatically to reduce clutter on the display These contacts were getting buried near the noise floor so the system usually dropped them before they could be properly analyzed I started running a manual workaround during quiet watches I'd pull up the raw LOFAR gram on a secondary display window Standard protocol uses short integration times to catch fast transients like torpedoes or submarines maneuvering I did the opposite I disabled the automatic gain control and pushed the integration time out to 10 seconds Then I narrowed the FFT bin width down to 0 1 Hz This smears the display with noise but it allows a consistent low energy source to stack over time The random ocean noise averages out to gray while any coherent signal accumulates and becomes visible It's a way of maximizing processing gain when you're trying to pull something out of the noise floor

Facility was a commercial office park in a suburban area SCIF inside Two civilians one O6 They had raw acoustic data from what they said was a North Atlantic SOSUS array and asked me to find the signal I ran the same workaround I'd been using at AUTEC Extended integration time narrow bins AGC off Took me about forty minutes but I isolated three contacts their automated systems had missed completely They asked how I knew to look for it that way Told them I didn't know what I was looking for just been experimenting with different processing methods to see what the standard algorithms were filtering out It turned into a formal read in Additional NDAs Two polygraphs CI scope then lifestyle Waived unacknowledged SAP per 10 USC 119 They offered me a billet at a shore based facility doing similar work Accepted it Did that for about three years until I separated Can't discuss what I learned in that program Only thing I'll say is this If you're ever offered a way to extend your life indefinitely no matter what they promise you refuse it Can't explain why just don't I left active duty a few years back Contract work for two years then private sector Kept quiet until now Shag Harbour 1967 logged by Canadian DND as UFO entering water Divers searched for days found nothing Theory is object traveled underwater to sub detection facility near Shelburne met another craft departed Can't verify Sound propagates efficiently through SOFAR channel Anything wanting to cross ocean basins undetected would know how July 2019 USS Omaha filmed spherical object entering Pacific no splash Pentagon confirmed footage No wreckage recovered I stopped being surprised by these reports years ago NOAA says we've explored less than 20 of the ocean

41586622 Not my field I wasn't working in materials science 41586753 You're thinking about it wrong They don't need armed guards watching you the security is structural Everything happens in a SCIF No phones no devices of any kind You get physically searched going in and pass through a metal detector coming out The spaces have tempest shielding for RF isolation no windows white noise generators Some facilities have copper mesh built into the walls Inside everything is compartmented You only see the data relevant to your specific task I was brought in to process acoustic signatures so that's what I saw Didn't see intercept reports didn't see recovery operations didn't see material analysis or get read into policy discussions Different people in different SCIFs working different programs Nobody has the whole picture except maybe a handful at the very top and I'm not even sure about that The data itself never leaves the system You work on air gapped terminals with no USB ports and no network connection Results get printed on a specific printer that logs every page and those pages stay in the SCIF in a GSA approved safe You can't take notes home or sketch something on a napkin at lunch Can't discuss it outside the SCIF even with other people who have clearances They polygraph you regularly Not just at the initial read in but every six months sometimes more if something concerns the security officer They ask specific questions about whether you've discussed classified information or attempted to remove materials You lie the box catches it your clearance gets pulled and you face possible prosecution You also sign documents acknowledging criminal penalties under the Espionage Act Title 18 sec 793 and 798 Then there's SF 312 where you acknowledge in writing that unauthorized disclosure causes irreparable injury to national security

41590775 let's do this super simple filter if you ever get the chance to get near that data again a sampling rate 500khz is decent enough more or less any hydrophone can do that in addition to chinese piezos if you want to make your own 52hz whale catcher on that waveform calculate a series of moving averages such that the first moving average window creates 1 and only 1 inflection point on the data either concave or convex it doesn't matter create a series of additional moving averages such that the total number of inflection points aka first derivative zero crossing are near a prime number for math reasons a set of moving average curves are made allowing better interpolation between points eventually arriving at a narrow sampling window of 1khz to get a good sample rate of 500 data points per oscillation at the lowest range instead of calculating the spectrum distribution off of a fourier transform on the original data just use the dx dy values for each inflection point pair on the moving average smoothed signal set using that smoothed and interpolated data subtract it from the original waveform this yields a noise floor dataset which can be analyzed for correlation with your 52hz ultranarrowband signal this is more or less a convolution and denoising filter but it gets the point across higher sampling rates better results anyway something like that can be implemented in a stock off the shelf DSP some decent piezos from digikey and a few arrays built by pcbway jlcpcb total cost for a 10 000 element sonar array some processing elements a data storage pile and maybe a graphics card to render it ends up bring around 20k you'll need a boat and some clever fiberglass work but making a sonobuoy to beat the specs of what we and every other modern navy dips to find submarines is stupid easy your 52hz whales are easily tracked on that

This is a story that happened to me around the year 2000 and it is something I will never forget It all happened on a two week trip that I took with my family It was winter and we had gone to a house that belonged to my grandparents The house was in the countryside It was me a cousin my parents an uncle and an aunt It was not a big house but the area around it was huge It was a house in the middle of the woods and there was nothing to do there because of the isolation The city was far away and there was no houses nearby The only thing we had was a swimming pool and there was no television The water was always freezing though We mostly passed time with the soccer ball we had My cousin and I were always creative whenever we weren't playing with the ball we were making up stories it did not take long for the ghost stories start We spent a long time seeing who would get more frightened This wore off after a while and nothing scared us Halfway through the trip the adults were sick and tired of staying there all the time too They decided to go out into the city My cousin and I did not wanted to do tourist shit so we stayed in the house We were 15 and 14 now and so they didn't think twice about leaving us They decided we could fend for ourselves When night fell they left and we stayed there playing cards Time went by and the temperature dropped A strong mist settled in the area However the fog was so intense that you could not see anything more than twenty yards away from the house I made a comment about the fog I was like Yeah it's in a mist like that where the devil appears Soon my cousin forgot the cards and went to the window and began to nag me He dared me to go outside I was like no way I'm going outside in this cold The conversation was more or less this for the next half an hour him daring me to leave and me refusing Until he said Dude I think I saw something out there

comment: ITT we discuss the TI phenomenon which has exploded in relevance as the number of people suddenly afflicted with symptoms resembling schizophrenia or suddenly proclaiming religious communion demonic possession or extraterrestrial contact have risen sharply since around 2020 For some it's an obvious diagnosis but the symptoms are incredibly inconsistent with what mainstream science says of the disorders that the layman may mistake this thing as For those suffering from it it goes by many other names A lot of us go down the therapy and meds route but eventually when those stop working and nothing changes as those voices we all experience take the mask off and behave in ways a mental illness never could such as reacting in real time with planning and malice to our every thought and action it makes sense that we'd look externally for answers Turns out it's a hell of a rabbit hole While it's impossible to figure out specifics we do know it ain't supernatural We don't know who or what is doing it but the technology required to cause the effects we experience exists and has existed for a long time albeit in more primitive forms This thread is here for discussing the topic and to offer resources that may help any targeted persons figure out their own situation and work through it in a healthy proactive kind of way You probably know as much as I do by now that there isn't a reasonable way to put a stop to it but fortunately you can live a relatively normal life in spite of the ongoing harassment The more I post these and the more documentation I produce the more oppressive my perps become in direct proportion to how much material gets shared Yet they can never stop us from doing so Curious isn't it given all the bluster they spout about having control

41566051 41566472 Well the line is a bit vague it depends on what the relationship between Gnosticism and Proto Orthodoxy is how they are connected and how they are divided First of all there is no reason to believe in any Non Christian origin of Gnosticism not mentioning Valentinians or Marcionites for obvious reasons the Sethites are often considered to have existed before Christianity as a Barbeloite Sect and a Sethian Sect both inside Judaism that came in contact with Christianity and mixed together with eachother but our earliest sources point to Sethianism being a later development post 180 AD and even the earliest Barbeloites are themselves based on the Ophite system and the earliest Ophite evidence we have points to a Christian origin where the Christ Savior is central and not identified with anyone else but Jesus Seth is mention but given no importance Outside of these Sethians Classic Gnostics there are the Carpocratians and the Simon derived Gnostics Simonians Menandrists Basilideans and Satornilians all Post Christian all in one way or another Middle Platonic even the Ophite system is just a Neopythagorean one adapted for Christian theology So now that we know that these Gnostics were Christian why did they not get along with Proto Orthodoxy The standard answer is that Proto Orthodoxy was evil ignorant malicious but the truth is just that the Gnostics were like the Ghulats in early Islam they were Exaggerators If you look at our Qumran or Hellenistic Jewish texts and our Nag Hammadi texts and compare them they are two different worlds totally disconnected from eachother if you compare our earliest Proto Orthodox texts to Qumran and Hellenistic Judaism and those same texts then to Nag Hammadi they fit in with both

I had an epiphany today for a long time I asked myself what happens if someone does not truly believe in Jesus Christ but accepts his offer anyway What if you say I'm a Christian I accept Jesus Christ as my lord and savior and you live in christianly ways but part of you still thinks he may not have existed been the son of God performed miracles or so on What happens to these people Then something hit me It isn't that you need to have zero doubt about Christ's story or existence but that you can believe it MIGHT be true and you are sacrificing your better judgement to have faith That's the key faith You are saying I don't know if it's true but I'm willing to be wrong or embarass myself for the pursuit of believing it might be true This is the mustard seed the tiniest bit of deviation from the norm that separates you from the masses in whom no part believe it could be true This alone demonstrates belief If I asked you to bet 10 dollars on the sun not setting tomorrow you probably wouldn't take the deal From your worldly experience and your worldly logic you would very likely think the sun will obviously set tomorrow Sounds like a good way to lose money However what if you threw caution to the wind and said Hey fuck it why not and gave me the money The sun would most likely set you'd most likely lose your money but you had FAITH that in some tiny inconceivable way it could happen Herein we see the teaching it is not about believing completely but partially There are many Christians upon this earth but relatively few who would embarass themselves to believe So as it were do not feel bad if you have doubt but relish the fact that you can believe even if only for a moment in spite of worldly pretenses This is faith I like to think the more faith we have in the improbable the more it will come probable in our lives Peace and love Do not give up my brothers

41576026 It's not a non issue There's no reason to remove it Filioque is just right understanding and infuriates semi Arians But it shouldn't be a matter for division The divide doesn't come from the authority of the Pope who has always been recognized by all parties as first among equals it comes from those who would rather kowtow to their secular heads of state in matters of religion For those national churches that have become appendages of the state submission to the Pope would constitute an undermining of the power secular authorities have been exercising over the church Because no longer would the church be divided along national lines serving national interests but be unified under a single universal banner serving a universal interest This is an old conceit in the east where the Emperor was hailed as the head of and supreme authority over the church A similar situation transpired in the Lutheran and Anglican state churches after the reformation which was really just a sundering OFC the western church struggled with this too many times the Investiture Controversy and Two Swords doctrine spring to mind This practice of allowing secular magnates to install bishops would result in disaster after the Turks took over Constantinople and appointed a patriarch who was rabidly anti Latin to back out of the Council of Florence in which it was agreed that the schism would be healed The Turks did not want Christian unity because that would mean a unified front of resistance So they installed someone who would keep the division going Later when the protestants would further undermine the edifice of Christendom the Turks would likewise support them For more on the right and anciently recognized separation of church from the imposition of the state see St Ambrose's letter to his sister Separation of church and state is not to protect the state from the church but the church from the state yFg6LBa4

A book is just a medium for transmitting thoughts from brain to brain Reading is done for the benefit of the reader As long as the ideas are transmitting and the reader is deriving benefit there's no meaningful difference between ways of reading Some ways can be more practical than others in a given situation but then the difference is only circumstantial There are also personal preferences but again that's hardly philosophical If you enjoy certain ways of reading the choice of a medium matters to you but it's only ever a preference it tells something of you rather than the nature of reading or of reality at large You shouldn't try to pass your bias off as holding a deeper truth

24920050 24920056 You shouldn't try to pass your bias off as holding a deeper truth how about the bias that reading is anything like transmitting thoughts You're treating the act of reading like downloading information or data transfer To say that a reader should be aiming for any kind of transfer accuracy is a normative claim about how one ought to read Reading at least as often serves an aesthetic inspirational function which largely independent of content This function will be influenced by the medium Further even within the data transfer paradigm humans aren't computers The rate of transfer impacts the kinds of data that will be pulled IE surface level reading vs an actual deep reading of the text Digital readers vs physical books are known to impact the speed and comprehension although this might just be due to users being able to adjust font sizes and backlighting to their specific needs Unfortunately for your stupid ass this is the objectively correct truth

subject: Is Liberalism the Final Stage of Human Development
comment: Are we at the end of History Are we the Last Man Or is Fukuyama's thesis as Derrida says a gospel for the death of Marxism The protocol of our conference evokes the example of the book by Francis Fukuyama The End of History and the Last Man Is not what we have here a new gospel the noisiest the most mediatized m diatique the most successful one on the subject of the death of Marxism as the end of history This work frequently resembles it is true the disconcerting and tardy by product of a footnote nota bene for a certain Koj ve who deserved better Yet the book is not as bad or as naive as one might be led to think by the frenzied exploitation that exhibits it as the finest ideo logical showcase of victorious capitalism in a liberal democracy which has finally arrived at the plenitude of its ideal if not of its reality In fact although it remains essentially in the tradition of Leo Strauss relayed by Allan Bloom the grammar school exercise of a young industrious but come lately reader of Koj ve and a few others one must recognize that here or there this book goes beyond nuance and is sometimes suspensive to the point of indecision To the questions elaborated in its own fashion it on occasion ingenuously adds so as to cover all the bases what it calls two broad responses from the Left and the Right respectively p xxii It would thus merit a very close analysis This evening we will have to limit ourselves to what concerns the general structure of a thesis indispensable precisely in the very structure of its logic in the formulation of its formula to the anti Marxist conjuration It is by design of course that we called it a moment ago a gospel Why a gospel Why would the formula here be neotestamentary This book claims to bring a positive response to a question whose formation and formulation are never interrogated in themselves

The truth is that the majority of people today accept their conditions even as they are unsatisfied with them They are disillusioned and frustrated to an increasingly hostile degree but are resolutely opposed to interrogating their own systems which produce this discontent The final answers for them will always come from pointing the fingers at others In the end they will say well at least I'm not like those other people The entire political spectrum at the end of the day is thus united around a consensus believing that we don't have ENOUGH liberal democracy and everything would be all fine if we sorted it out better The issue for them is that they don't have enough freedom enough equality enough stability because it has been taken away from them by capitalism or Islam or immigrants or whatever ALL of our politics today amounts to this and it effectively presumes that liberalism is the ultimate truth regardless of anything that these so called critics of liberalism claim today The big mistake that all these political scientists and politicians are making post Trump is that they view the current disorders in liberal democracies as an external assault on their system rather than a product of it And this is because they're all working one way or another to protect it from the most racist diehard MAGA chud to the wokest millennial leftist In that sense Fukuyama IS correct It doesn't matter if liberalism won't eventually politically dominate the world though it still does all that matters is if people will think of something beyond liberalism as a philosophy or system And they do not And so whatever problems that come from liberalism will keep gnawing at us until it's too late because we're busy complaining about other systems instead all a result of our implicit recognition that liberalism is indeed the end of history and the objective truth

Is this boring as shit already 1 2 GO PROGENITORS Ivan s eyes scanned the text of the flier briefly which had landed on his desk this morning while he was attending his daily mandatory Graduates Seminar It was 6 47 AM in early September with the sunrise gleaming through the windows directly above Ivan s laboratory desk in Bowen Hall A new school year had started which while having little impact on Ivan s research work did mean a return of the greater student body and with it renewed enthusiasm for major activities on campus specifically college football and lining up in one of the only two Quicken Eats locations on campus where students would wait 45 minutes for takeout This was the Holden Ulbricht Myer Metallurgical Institute of Southeastern Colorado HUMMIS Ivan a postdoctoral research fellow at the Institute picked up the flier and would seem alone in wondering how such a specialized organization obtained the financial and emotional wherewithal to sustain such an incredibly mediocre athletics program The HUMMIS Progenitors had not won a game against anyone in the conference since their massive upset over Southern Arizona Miner s University SAMU in 2012 Not only that but this singular victory came eight months after a temporary federal restriction on gypsum mining which happened to sustain Yuma County and with it practically anyone employed within a hundred mile radius of SAMU This is important to note only insofar as it demonstrates that the HUMMIS Progenitors were as obscure as they were unable to beat other small college teams without major localized economic disruptions Ivan discarded the flyer after a brief moment and began to review his latest notes Standing at 6 3 he was a tall slender figure who in spite of his height was relatively unimposing He had medium length dark curly hair with large thick oval glasses and a light lisp of which he had grown tired trying to conceal Some would say he looked funny although he fell more on the side of being offensively plain rather than outright ugly He was soft spoken highly reserved and by certain accounts not terribly bright Perhaps that is unfair to say in this way though his memory was functional and he was a bright scientific thinker which contributed to his success up until now However he was slow to speak often absent minded aloof and generally uninterested in what was going on around him unless it affected him personally or his work Even then he didn t care much one way or another as long as he got paid

24889583 Pretty stupid My opinion of Philip Larkin has declined significantly Even if everyone could read sheet music it would still be an inferior means of experiencing the music because it's a thousandfold less expressive than when performed The physical ears remain superior to the mental ears What is missed in hearing spoken poetry is either less consequential or can be later studied on the page in the same way that the average music fan does not hear everything that is going on in the performance of a Beethoven symphony but can go to the score later to better understand it Larkin is a depending upon a very modern idea of what poetry is but the greatest poets in history have pretty much all written verse either very closely to music or with the intention of performance Yes the performance can sometimes get in the way if the performer is bad but great poetry is significant enough to allow for an endless variety in how it is performed without its essential nature being tarnished As Tennyson said Poetry is like shot silk with many glancing colours Every reader must find his own interpretation according to his own ability and according to his sympathy with the poet

24916406 Peterson is counting on noone pointing out to him that Christianity is not like Shintoism or some other religion that is mosty about ways of life Fundamental and almost unique to Abrahamic religion is the idea that what matters most is believing sincerely in the claims it's making The Greeks cared about honouring the gods but placed far less emphasis on in one's own mind believing certain things For a Christian what makes 'murder is wrong' true is that God says it is so For Peterson it's true because such a law has instrumental value for the kind of society he wants to live in You see this in his misunderstanding of Nietzsche he claims that Nietzsche believes that truth serves life and takes this to mean that 'useful' beliefs are truer than say 1 1 2 You'll notice that he says that certain Bible stories are 'truer than true' and he means that literally for him their historical truth is secondary to the supposed utilitarian value of their moral Incidentally what Nietzsche really means is that what we believe is a will to truth is in fact an elaborated will to power this is in a subtle way the exact opposite of what Peterson claims truth in a non moral sense very often is harmful to life N explicitly states in fact that the value of a belief to life has no bearing on its truth whatsoever In short when Peterson says that Christianity is true what he means is that it's pragmatic for most people in his ideal society to believe in it He can call that Christianity if he wants but nearly all sincere Christians would hold that he is damned simply because he doesn't endorse the Nicene Creed

1 2 You could be actually exploring and refining different models but instead like your post shows your entire field spends more time actively justifying not doing science with constant appeals to the authority of whatever school you tribally align with for political reasons Economics is actually doing too much science as you understand it For example central banks use very advanced models to guide their policies but in the end they always have pernicious effects because they don't rapidly adapt to new information which wasn't included in the models to which decentralised economic agents could adapt For example if central banks set a relatively low interest rate to stimulate the economy companies can that way have access to cheaper funding and fund new projects in a moment of technological innovation there may be funding for many companies whose projects are shaky and risky because they don't use in proper ways the new technology companies which wouldn't have got funding if the interest rates hadn't been low since interest rates are the price of time and risk and it is artificially low this time as the central bank didn't know about this new technology when they set the interest rate In a decentralised banking system where every bank fully estimates whether or not the projects are consistent they already do it now but not fully because the central bank pushes private banks to investment or to liquidity with the interest rates the banks who trusted and funded the shaky projects would lose money or even go bankrupt and others who didn't trust or trusted the companies which best used the new technology would maximise profits and that experience could be useful for banks in the future to set their own interest rates Central banking distorts this discovery and optimization process because they prompt interest rates to the direction they want hindering experimentation and because they bailout private banks if they go bankrupt after the mistakes they have incentivised

The Great Plains by Walter Prescott Webb Walter Prescott Webb's 1931 book The Great Plains is a foundational work in American history that argues the region's unique environment its treeless flat terrain and subhumid climate profoundly shaped the institutions and culture of those who settled there Webb's central thesis is that the 98th meridian acted as an institutional fault line forcing significant changes to European and American ways of life and he identifies key technological adaptations like the revolver barbed wire and windmill as crucial to Anglo conquest The book is structured around eleven questions Webb posed about the region's history and the challenges of settlement

24916395 this question bugs me surely every good book changes your life for the better because they all feed into your soul and imagination and sensibility and therefore they shape how the world looks and feels how it enters into your consciousness and what your consciousness makes of it without books the world would not exist for you in the same way and you would not be the same person when you look out at a landscape and feel it invested with meaning and history or when you meet a new person and try to sense who they are and what that means to you you're doing so on the basis of the deep layers of experience sedimented in your soul good books are a uniquely powerful source of such experience you meet an old college friend of your dad and when he reaches for a handshake it's suddenly a jovial priest from an 18th century novel reaching out to grasp your hand and you realise that what you've sensed in him is also the gravity and the secret sadness of that priest a green light flares past in the night beyond the train window and it flares with the mysterious aura it does because it reminds you of what technology meant to 1920s modernists liberating and awful and alien you sense signals pulsing across remotest Eurasian steppes and the clammy iphone in your hand and the vocal fried podcast you've been listening to suddenly seem a commercialised unimaginative betrayal of that possibility culture allows the world to disclose itself language as they say is the dwelling house of being

24880560 24880560 The writing is very very good but not in a way that maps well onto writing as associated with movies novels stories Its strength is not in clean narrative arcs or well written effective emotional moments or characters It is a world with a history that does not want to be discovered but which if paid attention to slowly reveals whats going on beneath the surface It is interesting because it makes worldbuilding not a neutral framework for a world but something that tries to trick you fool you into compliance And it is a great commentary on what history ultimately is fact and interpretation happening at the same time What we piece together are traces of facts and interpretations that those that make history would prefer you to forget I think this way of writing antagonistic lore is very unique to the medium of games where that kind of information can be hidden in things most players ignore or take for granted item descriptions small details in textures enemy and item placements and so on The closest literature has gotten to something like that is Pale Fire and it essentially does it by 'gamifying' the book making you flip back and forth taking multiple routes through the book

24921966 Psychosis simulation for the curious Source of inspiration for the literate and the artistic Form of cope for the marginal A way to justify their own disease for the mentally ill Kraig isn't the first or the biggest example that magic and occultism is bunk Crowley Chosen to be the prophet of a new age Struggled with money the second half of his life Austin Osman Spare Father of Chaos Magic Died drunk and dirt poor Andrew Chumbley Another chosen prophet Died at 32 from asthma And these are the major lights The celebrities The poster boys for the magic and occult What does this say about magic itself Also two of them probably had mental illness stemming from autoimmune diseases Crowley and Chumbley had asthma But the problem with magic is that it lost its epistemological purpose after the Enlightenment and the Industrial Revolution Before Enlightenment magic was considered as a pragmatic model of reality and it was used to explain natural events and phenomenon in the way science is now used It was a more or less logical model that was studied and used because it was the only model learned people of medieval time had The moment science advanced all the learned men abandoned the magical model of the universe and focused on math physics chemistry biology psychology and so on As a result the only people left in the occulture were kooks of different traits homos schizos deviants criminals BPD dissociated sexual abuse victims Injuns women the marginal and the retarded The only sane element in the occult were the literate writers who used the occulture as a mine for inspiration And this process by the way wasn't limited to the West You can see the same process in India China and Japan where the learned speculations about the reality and forces of the world shifted from the esoteric Tantric model to a scientific one with the advance of modernity and the only people who remained Tantric were low IQ peasants the average Indian and the mentally ill

24920067 I've been thinking about exactly this same issue and here are the problems as I see it 1 Money is obviously a problem If you want to establish for example a new classically focused university you are going to need a lot of money These days most people are struggling just to get by It takes a lot of mental spiritual strength to simply opt out not to mention the physical toll and safety concerns associated with such a lifestyle So most people do what they can and they complain about what they cannot 2 Following from the first point the economic issues facing the West are systemic and don't have any political fix This is a huge issue that I haven't seen anybody willing to publicly address but the world has moved on in the last fifty years and the Western world is no longer indisputably a better place to live In fact most talent and money is currently moving out of it at a dizzying speed And I'm not going to sugar coat this point but it comes down to a single crucial variable the cost of labor A factory paying it's employees 25 dollars an hour simply cannot compete with a factory that can afford to pay its employees 5 an hour So what needs to happen is for Western workers to take a huge hit in their quality of life ability to afford goods and services etc But your average wagie is already worked to the bone just to pay their bills so you also need to massively cut the rate of profit for food rent transportation etc But obviously the powers that be and I'm talking about your local city representatives the people who you could go up and knock on their door tomorrow and argue this point with them yourself so don't fall into that trap of conspiratorial thinking where nobody is responsible for anything the powers that be are completely unwilling to commit to a plan that would for example decrease the property value ten fold And for good reason this would cause an economic death spiral and completely wipe out Western nations and governments So what do we do Grit our teeth and just accept the decline I guess and it can either be hard and fast or slow and drawn out but it's going to happen and there's not a single thing we can do about it I have ideas for things I personally would change Ideas for new modalities of conducting politics But obviously I don't want to go into too much detail here But at the end of the day we still need to eat so that will always be a concern 4chan in general is a good platform to crowdsource punditry Most of my most successful opinions I've stolen verbatim from this place Any time I've thinking of a new piece of demagoguery I come here to workshop it The medium is the problem I guess One last note concerning long term visions All changes are short term over a long enough time frame Starting a family is almost certainly more long lasting than just about any other endeavour I can think of you shouldn't be so quick to dismiss it

24920061 The other day I happened to take up Milton's Paradise Lost which threw me into strange contemplations In this as in all other productions of modern art it is the personality of the artist that gives interest to his work The subject is detestable externally not without a certain imposing grandeur but internally worm eaten and hollow The springs of action and the situations that belong to them are in some few cases natural and effective but the majority are lame and false and give one pain to realise At the same time it is an interesting man who speaks to us character feeling understanding learning poetical and oratorical genius and other excellent qualities he undoubtedly possesses in no common measure Nay more the singular accident that as a revolutionary politician he paints the devil with more effective touches than the angels has a great influence on the design and composition of the poem and again the accident of the writer being blind adds not a little to the tone and colour of the book Paradise Lost therefore notwithstanding its radical defects as a work of art will maintain its place triumphantly in virtue of the majestic personality which it reveals I have lately read his 'Samson ' which has more of the antique spirit than any production of any other modern poet He is very great and his own blindness enabled him to describe with so much truth the situation of Samson Milton was really a poet one to whom we owe all possible respect

24922151 But in English I find that which is possessed by no other modern language and which as it were appropriates it to the drama It is a language made out of many and it has consequently many words which originally had the same meaning but in the progress of society those words have gradually assumed different shades of meaning Take any homogeneous language such as German and try to translate into it the following lines But not to one in this benighted age Is that diviner inspiration given That burns in Shakspeare's or in Milton's page The pomp and prodigality of heaven Gray's Stanzas to Bentley In German it would be necessary to say 'the pomp and spendthriftness of heaven ' because the German has not as we have one word with two such distinct meanings one expressing the nobler the other the baser idea of the same action The monosyllabic character of English enables us besides to express more meaning in a shorter compass than can be done in any other language In truth English may be called the harvest of the unconscious wisdom of various nations and was not the formation of any particular time or assemblage of individuals Hence the number of its passionate phrases its metaphorical terms not borrowed from poets but adopted by them Our commonest people when excited by passion constantly employ them if a mother lose her child she is full of the wildest fancies and the words she uses assume a tone of dignity for the constant hearing and reading of the Bible and Liturgy clothes her thoughts not only in the most natural but in the most beautiful forms of language
